title: Percy Bysshe Shelley 1
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
lines: In realms where sunlight wanes to eve,
And shadows dance with secrets weave,
A whisper echoes through the glade,
Where dreams, like petals, gently fade.
Ode to the mystic, ethereal night,
Where stars unveil their ancient light,
The moon, a pearl in midnight's sea,
Sings ballads of eternity.

title: Percy Bysshe Shelley 2
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
lines: Oh, Shelley! Thy spirit soars,
Where truth and beauty freely pours,
A rebel heart, a fervent soul,
In nature's hymn, you find your goal.
Through meadows green and mountains high,
A hymn to life, a lullaby,
The poet's pen, a magic wand,
Conjuring dreams on twilight's pond.

title: Percy Bysshe Shelley 3
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
lines: In every drop of morning dew,
The echoes of your verses brew,
A symphony of words divine,
In which, immortal thoughts entwine.
So let us wander through the night,
Where Shelley's spirit takes its flight,
Among the stars and moonlit streams,
Forever lost in poetic dreams.

title: Percy Bysshe Shelley 4
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
lines: Hail to thee, ethereal minstrel of the skies,
Whose melody in the azure realm lies,
Invisible, yet thy song resounds profound,
A symphony of joy, a celestial sound.
Thou art the poet of the boundless air,
Thy notes, a sonnet beyond compare,
Ascending higher on thy wings unseen,
Thou art the spirit of the heavens' serene.

title: Percy Bysshe Shelley 5
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
lines: In thee, the soul of nature finds its voice,
In thee, the wilderness and woods rejoice,
Thy music floats upon the zephyr's breath,
A melody that conquers fear and death.
Oh, how thy song enchants the listening ear,
As thou dost soar, untouched by mortal fear,
Thou art a symbol of unfettered grace,
A symbol of the beauty time cannot efface.
Sing on, immortal songster of the blue,
Thy strains, a hymn to all that's pure and true,
And as thou vanish into realms unknown,
Thy echo in our hearts shall ever be shown.

title: Percy Bysshe Shelley 6
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
lines: Behold the azure, vast and deep,
Where dreams and visions softly seep,
As poets dare to pierce the veil,
Their verses like a nightingale.
On gossamer wings, the zephyrs sigh,
Through realms of thought, they flutter by,
In every breeze, a tale untold,
In every leaf, a story's hold.

title: Samuel Coleridge 1
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: It is an ancient Mariner,
And he stoppeth one of three.
'By thy long gray beard and gleaming eye,
Now wherefore stopp'st thou me?
The Wedding-Guest sat on a stool;
He cannot choose but stay;
And thus spake on that gray-beard wise,
The Mariner, that way:

title: Samuel Coleridge 2
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: The sea was smooth, the sky serene,
No tempest in the air;
But eftsoons a frightful change,
A storm did suddenly tear.
The ship, it plunged and tossed about,
The waves, they roared in glee;
The Wedding-Guest sat frozen still,
His eyes fixed on the sea.

title: Samuel Coleridge 3
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: The curse befell the ancient ship,
The crew turned ghostly pale;
No wind to fill their lifeless sails,
No hope within their sail.
Albatross, an omen fair,
Came gliding through the fog;
With crossbow, I, the Mariner,
Shot the creature in the bog.

title: Samuel Coleridge 4
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: A curse, a spell, befell us all,
The ship stood still, no wind to blow;
The Albatross around my neck,
A weight of guilt, a tale of woe.
Water, water, everywhere,
And all the boards did shrink;
Water, water, everywhere,
Nor any drop to drink.

title: Samuel Coleridge 5
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: And through the drifts, the snowy clifts,
Did send a dismal sheen;
Nor shapes of man nor beasts we kenâ€”
The ice was all between.
And still the curse, it lingered on,
The specter of the bird;
I wandered, cursed, through icy waste,
By unseen forces stirred.

title: Samuel Coleridge 6
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: In sleep, the dead men stood by me,
A ghastly crew, my mates;
Each one cursed to a lifeless fate,
A punishment that grates.
The Wedding-Guest, he shuddered now,
His soul gripped by dismay;
The Mariner, his tale unfurled,
Continued on his way.
And thus, through storm and shipwreck dire,
I carry my remorse;
A lesson learned through endless night,
Upon life's haunted course.

title: Samuel Coleridge 7
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: In Xanadu did Kubla Khan
A stately pleasure dome decree;
Where Alph, the sacred river, ran
Through caverns measureless to man
Down to a sunless sea.
So twice five miles of fertile ground
With walls and towers were girdled round:
And there were gardens bright with sinuous rills,
Where blossomed many an incense-bearing tree;
And here were forests ancient as the hills,
Enfolding sunny spots of greenery.

title: Samuel Coleridge 8
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: But oh! That deep and cavernous delight
Was shattered by a dream within a dream,
As I, the poet, sought to recreate
The glory of the ruler's opulent scheme.
A vision of the dome, resplendent, grand,
Rose in my mind, a creation of the land.
The palace walls, with turrets tall,
Echoed with the voices of the waterfall.

title: Samuel Coleridge 9
author: Samuel Coleridge
lines: Yet, ere the vision could be fully formed,
A disruption, a noise, an intruder stormed.
The dream of Xanadu began to fade,
Like sunlight filtered through a forest glade.
A poem incomplete, a dream unfulfilled,
As if the threads of inspiration were spilled.
Kubla Khan's pleasure dome, lost in a sigh,
A fragment of beauty in the poet's eye.

title: Robert Browning 1
author: Robert Browning
lines: Beneath the boughs where shadows meet,
A hedge stands, silent, incomplete.
Its branches weave a secret tale,
Of whispers carried by the gale.
Along the winding, narrow lane,
Where sunlight dances through the rain,
The hedgerow guards its ageless lore,
A keeper of the evermore.

title: Robert Browning 2
author: Robert Browning
lines: Its thorns, a subtle, guarded fence,
Yet within, a world immense.
Each leaf, a page of ancient rhyme,
A verdant book, lost in time.
The blackbird perched on tangled twig,
Sings a song both old and big.
The hedgerow listens, bends its ear,
To echoes only it can hear.

title: Robert Browning 3
author: Robert Browning
lines: In quiet moments, dusk to dawn,
The hedgerow dreams, its spirit drawn
From roots that anchor deep in earth,
A witness to each season's birth.
And when the twilight whispers low,
The hedgerow murmurs soft and slow,
Its secrets shared with moonlit night,
A confidant in muted light.

title: Robert Browning 4
author: Robert Browning
lines: Beneath the canopy of endless sky,
Where verdant meadows and green fields lie,
A path unfolds, a journey undefined,
Through woods and valleys, in the quiet mind.
Each step a dance with shadows and with light,
A pilgrim's progress, lost in pure delight.
The earth beneath, a silent, steadfast guide,
As through the open land, my footsteps glide.

title: Robert Browning 5
author: Robert Browning
lines: The winding path, a muse for wandering thought,
In solitude, profound connection sought.
The rustling leaves, a gentle, calming song,
As nature's whispers carry me along.
The distant hills, a tranquil, distant dream,
A landscape painted in a hazy gleam.
The world unfolds in hues of green and blue,
A canvas touched by morning's golden dew.
And as I tread through fields of amber grain,
A quiet solace fills my heart and brain.
For in these moments, paths become divine,
A sacred journey through the grand design.

title: George Eliot 1
author: George Eliot
lines: In the loom of life, the weaver sits,
Hands weathered by the threads of fate.
With each passing day, the shuttle flits,
A tale woven, a story ornate.
The warp of time, the weft of choice,
A fabric rich with hopes and fears.
In every strand, you'll hear a voice,
Whispering through the passing years.

title: George Eliot 2
author: George Eliot
lines: The weaver's gaze, profound and wise,
Threads entwining, destinies bound.
In the loom's embrace, the present lies,
A canvas where our lives are found.
Yet, in the chaos of the woven art,
A harmony emerges, a guiding hand.
For every twist, a purpose to impart,
A cosmic design we can't understand.
O weaver of destiny, with hands so deft,
Guide the loom with kindness and grace.
In the tapestry of life, each soul is left,
A mark, a pattern, a unique trace.

title: George Eliot 3
author: George Eliot
lines: In the quiet town of Middlemarch,
Where lives entwine, and destinies arch.
A web of stories, both small and grand,
Unfolding in the heart of the land.
Dorothea, with dreams so vast,
In marriage, found shadows cast.
A journey through passions, both bright and dark,
In the tapestry of life, an enduring mark.

title: George Eliot 4
author: George Eliot
lines: Lydgate, a man of science and strife,
Caught in the currents of ambition and life.
The complexities of love and art,
Echo through Middlemarch's every part.
Rosamond, with beauty and pride,
In her heart, a tumultuous tide.
Choices made in the name of desire,
Igniting the town with a secret fire.

title: George Eliot 5
author: George Eliot
lines: George Eliot, the omniscient guide,
Peering into each character's side.
In Middlemarch, the echoes persist,
A reflection of the human twist.
In every page, a mirror held,
To the dreams and follies dwelled.
George Eliot's words, a timeless march,
Through the profound echoes of Middlemarch.

title: Mary Oliver 1
author: Mary Oliver
lines: Beneath the canvas of the waking sky,
Where dawn unfolds, and day draws nigh,
The meadowlark, a poet in disguise,
Sings a hymn to the morning rise.
With feathers dipped in the hues of gold,
It weaves a tale, both soft and bold.
In the meadow's silence, the melody weaves,
A sonnet of joy, the heart perceives.

title: Mary Oliver 2
author: Mary Oliver
lines: Each note, a dewdrop on the grass,
A moment seized as the shadows pass.
The meadowlark, a messenger of light,
Carries the dawn into the quiet night.
Oh, morning troubadour with wings of air,
Your song, a prayer, a whispered care.
In the meadow's embrace, your notes align,
A psalm to the earth, a hymn divine.

title: Mary Oliver 3
author: Mary Oliver
lines: In the heart of the forest, where shadows play,
A cathedral of trees in quiet array.
Leaves whisper secrets in the dappled light,
A symphony of green, an ancient rite.
Follow the path where ferns unfurl,
To a sacred space, a hidden world.
Moss-covered stones and roots that wind,
A sanctuary for the quiet mind.

title: Mary Oliver 4
author: Mary Oliver
lines: Beneath the canopy, where the sunlight peeks,
Nature's language, a language that speaks.
In the hush of the pines, a whispered song,
A connection ancient, timeless, and strong.
Listen closely, as the breezes tell,
Stories of the forest, where mysteries swell.
In the rustle of leaves, the secrets unfold,
A communion of spirits, a story untold.
In the forest's embrace, where the soul can quiver,
I find myself lost and found in its whisper.
Mary Oliver, in nature's verse, I stand,
A humble poet in this enchanted land.

title: Wendell Berry 1
author: Wendell Berry
lines: In the golden fields where the sunlight weaves,
The farmer walks among the amber sheaves.
Hands worn like the earth he tills each day,
A steward of the land, in work and in play.
With fingers calloused, but gentle and kind,
He tends to the soil, heart and soul aligned.
In every furrow, in every seed sown,
A testament to a life deeply known.

title: Wendell Berry 2
author: Wendell Berry
lines: The plow turns the earth with a rhythmic grace,
A dance with the seasons, a familiar embrace.
The farmer's hands, weathered and wise,
Hold the secrets of both lows and highs.
He knows the language of the whispering breeze,
And the secrets that rustle through the trees.
In the cycle of life, he takes his part,
A poet of the land, with a plow for his heart.

title: Wendell Berry 3
author: Wendell Berry
lines: Beneath the shade where the willows weep,
The creek sings a lullaby soft and deep.
Its waters ripple in a gentle refrain,
A melody that carries away all pain.
Through meadows green and forests wild,
The creek meanders, an adventurous child.
Over stones worn smooth by time's embrace,
It weaves a tale of a quiet, watery grace.

title: Wendell Berry 4
author: Wendell Berry
lines: Underneath the sycamore's sprawling boughs,
The creek tells stories only nature allows.
A troubadour of the valley, a poet of the hills,
Its song echoes through the tranquil rills.
In the hush of dawn or the dusk's reprieve,
The creek's murmur is a solace to believe.
Wendell Berry, in the water's song,
I find a melody where I belong.

title: Chinaka Hodge 1
author: Chinaka Hodge
lines: In the city of echoes, where voices collide,
Concrete landscapes with stories to confide.
Neon lights flicker, a kaleidoscope gaze,
Where every street corner holds a thousand days.
Brick by brick, the history's inscribed,
On the walls of the city where dreams survived.
From the whir of traffic to the quiet park,
Each sound resonates, a heartbeat in the dark.

title: Chinaka Hodge 2
author: Chinaka Hodge
lines: In the alleyways where the poets scrawl,
Verse and protest on the urban sprawl.
Chinaka Hodge, in your rhythmic grace,
You echo the city's vibrant, resilient pace.
Through the alleys, down the boulevards,
A chorus of tales, a deck of urban cards.
In the city of echoes, where dreams unfold,
Each story whispered, each narrative told.

title: Chinaka Hodge 3
author: Chinaka Hodge
lines: In the pulse of the people, a revolutionary beat,
The rhythm of dissent, the drum of the street.
Chinaka's pen, a sword, a fierce advocate,
Crafting stanzas of change, powerful and intricate.
In the revolution's embrace, where fire ignites,
Words become weapons, poets take flight.
Echoing truths in the language of the unheard,
A manifesto written in every spoken word.

title: Chinaka Hodge 4
author: Chinaka Hodge
lines: Protest signs and poetic lines entwine,
In the fight for justice, in every rhyme.
From the picket lines to the open stage,
Chinaka Hodge, you ink the revolution's page.
Through the verses, a call to resist,
A poet's power, a clenched fist.
Revolutionary stanzas, loud and clear,
In the struggle for justice, we draw near.
